guides.title: How to Change Default Credentials
prerequisites: Access to the device's admin interface
Knowledge of the current default credentials
A secure method to store the new password
steps: Open a web browser and navigate to the device's IP address
Log in using the default credentials (check device documentation or search online for 'default password [device model]')
Navigate to Administration, Settings, or User Management section
Look for options like 'Change Password', 'User Settings', or 'Security'
Enter your current (default) password when prompted
Create a new strong password: at least 12 characters with uppercase, lowercase, numbers, and symbols
Confirm the new password
Save the changes and log out
Test logging in with the new credentials
Store the new password securely (password manager recommended)
guides.verification: Try logging in with the old default credentials - they should no longer work. Then verify you can log in with your new credentials.
common_mistakes: Using a password that's too simple or short
Not storing the new password securely
Using the same password as other devices

guides.title: How to Disable Telnet and Enable SSH
prerequisites: SSH client software if you need remote access
steps: Log into the device's administration interface
Navigate to Remote Management, Services, or Administration settings
Find Telnet service settings
Disable Telnet
If remote access is needed, enable SSH in the same section
Configure SSH settings (port, authentication method)
Save changes and restart the device if required
Test that Telnet port 23 is no longer accessible
If you enabled SSH, test that you can connect via SSH client
guides.verification: Use a port scanner or 'telnet [device-ip] 23' command to verify Telnet is no longer responding. If using SSH, test with 'ssh [username]@[device-ip]'.
common_mistakes: Disabling Telnet without enabling SSH when remote access is needed
Not restarting the device when required

guides.title: How to Secure SMB File Sharing
prerequisites: Admin access to the Windows system or NAS
Knowledge of which shares need to remain accessible
steps: Open Windows Features (Control Panel > Programs > Turn Windows features on or off)
Uncheck 'SMB 1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support' to disable SMBv1
Restart the computer
Open Computer Management > Shared Folders > Shares
Review all existing shares and remove unnecessary ones
For needed shares, right-click > Properties > Security
Remove 'Everyone' and add specific users/groups with minimum necessary permissions
Enable password-protected sharing in Network and Sharing Center
Configure Windows Firewall to restrict SMB access to specific IP ranges if needed
Enable SMB signing via Group Policy (Computer Configuration > Windows Settings > Security Settings > Local Policies > Security Options)
guides.verification: Use 'net share' command to list active shares. Try accessing shares from another computer to verify authentication is required.
common_mistakes: Forgetting to restart after disabling SMBv1

guides.title: How to Disable UPnP
steps: Log into your router's administration interface
Navigate to Advanced Settings, NAT, or Firewall section
Find UPnP settings (may be under 'Advanced' or 'Services')
Disable UPnP
Save changes
Review the Port Forwarding section for any unexpected rules
Remove any port forwarding rules you don't recognize
Manually add port forwarding rules for legitimate services you need
guides.verification: Use an online UPnP scanner or the GRC ShieldsUP! tool to verify UPnP is no longer responding.
common_mistakes: Not checking for existing port forwarding rules created by UPnP
Forgetting to manually configure needed port forwarding
Not saving changes before closing the interface

guides.title: How to Secure Remote Desktop
prerequisites: Understanding of your remote access needs
steps: If RDP is not needed, disable it: Settings > System > Remote Desktop > Off
If RDP is needed, enable Network Level Authentication (NLA)
Set up Windows Firewall to restrict RDP to specific IP addresses
Change the default RDP port from 3389 (optional but adds obscurity)
Enable account lockout policies (Local Security Policy > Account Policies)
Consider setting up a VPN for remote access instead of exposing RDP
Keep Windows updated with the latest security patches
Use strong passwords and consider multi-factor authentication
Set up Remote Desktop Gateway for additional security layer
guides.verification: Test RDP access only works from approved IP addresses. Verify NLA is required for connections.
common_mistakes: Exposing RDP directly to the internet without VPN
